data.title: Melinda Gates stepping down from Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation in June
data.meta_description: The former wife of the Microsoft founder said in a post on X Monday that she will leave with $12.5 billion to support work with women and families.
data.text:
Melinda French Gates said Monday she will resign from the charitable foundation she co-founded with her former husband, Microsoft founder Bill Gates. Her last day with the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation will be June 7, she announced on X.

âThis is not a decision I came to lightly. I am immensely proud of the foundation that Bill and I built together and of the extraordinary work it is doing to address inequities around the world," Gates wrote on X, adding, âThe time is right for me to move forward into the next chapter of my philanthropy.â

Founded in 2000, the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation is believed to be the second largest charitable foundation in the world with $69 billion in assets. According to its most recent annual report, it provided $7 billion in charitable support to global development, global health, gender equality and other charitable programs in 2022.

According to the foundation web site, the Gates âbelieve that all lives have equal value and they have always been determined to use their resources to create a world where everyone has the opportunity to lead a healthy and productive life.â

Bill and Melinda Gates were married for 27 years. They split up in 2022, after which Melinda Gates told the CBS Mornings TV show âthere just came a point in time where there was enough there that I realized it just wasnât healthy, and I couldât trust what we had.â

Gates is leaving the foundation with $12.5 billion under the terms of her agreement with her former husband.

âThis is a critical moment for women and girls in the U.S. and around the world â and those fighting to protect and advance equality are in urgent need of support,â Gates wrote on X.

She said she will share more about how she plans to advance her work with women and failies âin the near future.â
